API Documentation¶

The game class¶

Apart from a little helper function binomial_coeff.binomial_coeff() in it’s own module, the main code is in game.Game. This class uses a set of constants.

game.py module¶

game.py defines the MasterMind Game class.

class game.Game(slots=None, colors=None)¶

The Game class provides MasterMind game class and methods that can be used by various testing strategies.

colordict¶

Returns the colordict in self (a range).

create_code(solution_set=None)¶

Creates and returns a random code from a solution_set. By default the unrestricted set is used.

create_solution_generator()¶

Returns a generator for all solutions of self.

evaluator(trial, benchmark=None)¶

Returns the evaluation of a trial vs a benchmark. self.challenge is used as default benchmark.

reduce_solution_set(solution_set, trial, evaluation)¶

Returns a generator for all solutions in solution_set that are still possible based on trial and its evaluation.

set_challenge(solution_set=None)¶

Sets the challenge property with the possibility to restrict the codes to a custom solution_set.

slots¶

Returns the slots in self (a range).

binomial_coeff.py module¶

binomial_coeff.binomial_coeff(degree, coefficient)¶

Returns the binomial coefficient n choose k. n is the degree of the factorial and k the degree.

Solvers¶

Knuth’s algorithm (simplified)¶

solvers.knuth.knuth(game)¶

Run Knuth’s 5-guess algorithm on the given secret. adapted from http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20298190/mastermind-minimax-algorithm (see below for the code from stackoverflow)

The code is simplified in the way it treats ties in the minmax function. Instead of going to the next level to resolve ties, we simply take the first code that fulfills the minmax condition.

Returns the solution translated back into the game colors.

Brute force¶

solvers.brute_force.brute_force(game)¶

Solves MasterMind by running through generators. This saves memory but is dumb in the sense that it returns through possible solutions in lexical order.

Returns the solution translated back into the game colors.

Brute force optimized¶

solvers.brute_force_optimized.brute_force_optimized(game)¶

Solves MasterMind by running through generators. This saves memory but is dumb in the sense that it returns through possible solutions in lexical order. Returns the solution translated back into the game colors.

Brute force generator¶

solvers.brute_force_generator.brute_force_generator(game)¶

Solves MasterMind by running through generators. This saves memory but is dumb in the sense that it returns through possible solutions in lexical order.

Returns the solution translated back into the game colors.

Generator¶

solvers.generator.generator(game)¶

Solves MasterMind by running through generators. This saves memory but is dumb in the sense that it returns through possible solutions in lexical order.

Returns the solution translated back into the game colors.

Random walk¶

solvers.random_walk.random_walk(game)¶

Solves MasterMind by throwing out random codes. On average takes about 5 time n guesses, where n is the number of possible solutions of the Mastermind Game. For 64, this means about 6000 guesses.

Returns the solution translated back into the game colors.

Knuth’s algorithm faster (work in progress...)¶

solvers.knuth2.knuth(game)¶

Run Knuth’s 5-guess algorithm on the given secret. adapted from http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20298190/mastermind-minimax-algorithm (see below for the code from stackoverflow)

Returns the solution translated back into the game colors.

Constants¶

game.Game uses the literal string ‘abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz’ as potential keys for the game.Game.colordict() for translating the codes back to colors.
